vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** A third party attacking site can fake UI data - markets, categories and other

**Description:** A third party site can include a hidden iframe which can override "augur-node" configuration variable of a running augur application. This variable is persisted in localStorage. In the case of browser page reload (user action or browser/OS crash), the normal "augur-node" websockets endpoint will be replaced with the provided by attacker so that all the markets data, addresses and transactions can be masqueraded. 

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Start Augur application
  1. Open application
  1. Click on "markets" tab
  1. Start web socket server on port 8081 (different from the Augur one)
  1. Open HTML page with iframe which loads Augur's initial page with "augur-node" parameter overwritten by new value, for example 192.168.31.204:8081 in my test case
  1. Observe "Application" data tab in developer tools, the augur-node variable is set to new value: 192.168.31.204:8081
  1. Reload opened application (simulating user occasional reload or browser crash, or a user opening Augur app form bookmarks )
  1. Observe the log console of the web sockets server: you can see requests for categories, market data etc
  1. Observe the Augur application UI - no data is provided as the fake web sockets server has been called, we only need to add implementation and return fake data there to get user misdirected

## Impact: Can lead to fund and reputation loss

I also mentioned the danger of it in https://hackerone.com/bugs?subject=user&report_id=385125

Augur application should not be possible to load in an iframe and manipulate user's settings. For example, Gmail doesn't allow this.

Also, storing important configuration data in localStorage is a very bad practice

## Supporting Material/References:

  * HTML page implementing iframe which sets wrong data
  * server.js Simple web socket in node

## Impact

Can lead to fund and reputation loss

I also mentioned the danger of it in https://hackerone.com/bugs?subject=user&report_id=385125
title: Augur UI data can be completely replaced by an attacker which can lead to fund and reputation loss

activities.message: Forgot to add - in this example 192.168.31.204:8081 was just random IP address, so it seems augur-node can be queried not only form localhost, which makes this attack possible from outside server, not only local network or localhost
activities.markdown_message: Forgot to add - in this example 192.168.31.204:8081 was just random IP address, so it seems augur-node can be queried not only form localhost, which makes this attack possible from outside server, not only local network or localhost

activities.message: In order to run example server you'll need to "npm install --save ws" - the simple web sockets server for node I used for proof of concept. Then "node ./server.js"
activities.markdown_message: In order to run example server you'll need to "npm install --save ws" - the simple web sockets server for node I used for proof of concept. Then "node ./server.js"

activities.message: I continue investigation it and found that as web sockets are not subject of the "same origin policy", a third party website can easily DDOS local Augur node, creating many requests to locally running Augur app as there is no validation of the request integrity.
activities.markdown_message: I continue investigation it and found that as web sockets are not subject of the "same origin policy", a third party website can easily DDOS local Augur node, creating many requests to locally running Augur app as there is no validation of the request integrity.

activities.message: I haven't tested it manually, but it looks like the Ethereum node web socket endpoint also can be replaced in the same way

activities.message:
Hello!

Thank you for your submission! There are a few different issues in this post so I am going to address them separately here.

1. Augur App servers a webpage onto localhost:8080 and does not protect against serving within frames. You are correct this opens up the frame-jacking attack. I believe fixing this is the most important action item and can be donr quite simply using: https://github.com/helmetjs/frameguard. We've filed and issue to complete this task ASAP: https://app.clubhouse.io/augur/story/14538/patch-augur-app-express-server-with-helmet

2. Augur UI stores configuration in localStorage. This is an unfortunate issue because we have very few options for passing in configuration via IPFS, but it also opens up a security vulnerabuility because anyone accessing ipfs via ipfs.io can read/write to the same localstorage namespace. This is a known issue (from the time of design) and we're offering an option for people to clear their localstorage configuration to mitigate the issue.

3. Augur Node does not allow configurable WS origins. I do agree this is an improvement for anyone running a public AN, but is less of a security concern than a concern given AN's execution model. I believe we should add configurable WS origins options and set it to be `localhost` within augur-app.

Since (1) is the real data-security vulnerability here (as [2] is just a risk of running off a public IPFS endpoint and is documented) -- I say we tackle that first and then file issues for improvements around 2 and 3, both in documentation and configuration.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello!

Thank you for your submission! There are a few different issues in this post so I am going to address them separately here.

  1. Augur App servers a webpage onto localhost:8080 and does not protect against serving within frames. You are correct this opens up the frame-jacking attack. I believe fixing this is the most important action item and can be donr quite simply using: https://github.com/helmetjs/frameguard. We've filed and issue to complete this task ASAP: https://app.clubhouse.io/augur/story/14538/patch-augur-app-express-server-with-helmet

  2. Augur UI stores configuration in localStorage. This is an unfortunate issue because we have very few options for passing in configuration via IPFS, but it also opens up a security vulnerabuility because anyone accessing ipfs via ipfs.io can read/write to the same localstorage namespace. This is a known issue (from the time of design) and we're offering an option for people to clear their localstorage configuration to mitigate the issue.

  3. Augur Node does not allow configurable WS origins. I do agree this is an improvement for anyone running a public AN, but is less of a security concern than a concern given AN's execution model. I believe we should add configurable WS origins options and set it to be localhost within augur-app.

Since (1) is the real data-security vulnerability here (as [2] is just a risk of running off a public IPFS endpoint and is documented) -- I say we tackle that first and then file issues for improvements around 2 and 3, both in documentation and configuration.

activities.message:
Hello, thank you for your analysis of the issue

I just wanted to add, that 1. will probably be only partially solved by disabling loading Augur in iframe.
The other possibility would be to open a new JavaScript window in background or moved behind the screen borders. 
This would also reset local storage config values .
activities.markdown_message:
Hello, thank you for your analysis of the issue

I just wanted to add, that 1. will probably be only partially solved by disabling loading Augur in iframe.
The other possibility would be to open a new JavaScript window in background or moved behind the screen borders.
This would also reset local storage config values .

activities.message: Thinking more about it, if using local storage is inevitable, I would suggest performing additional check and ask user within the app, after page opened, does he really wants to change settings - in case config variables in local storage are going to be overwritten.

activities.message:
Hello!

We're exploring not using localstorage for the UI as served by Augur App, but enabling it (and some warnings/pop-ups) when served via IPFS.

Also, I've release Augur App v1.0.7 just now which addresses issue (1) for iframes, but as you said its not 100% foolproof (someone could just redirect the users), so this is why we're exploring (2) within augur-app.

Here's the updated version:
https://github.com/AugurProject/augur-app/releases/tag/v1.0.7

I've tested the new version in Chrome, Safari and Firefox, application is not possible to load in iframe anymore.

activities.message:
Hello

I continue trying to find new attack vectors related to the described issue and I think there is a new scenario.
I write it here as a comment, not as a separate issue because it's related.

Augur local application (while Augur app is not served through IPFS yet) is served via 127.0.0.1:8080

I would like to note that this is one of the most popular ports in use by applications with similar architecture - default Tomcat port, default testing port for many apps, web apps examples, default new Postgres web based UI client port, some of cryptocurrencies clients use this architecture (NXT for example) etc.

If I understood it correctly, all of these applications can read and write data from localStorage 127.0.0.1:8080. They are in fact share this data area with Augur client.
I other words, risk of one of such apps being compromised is multiplied by the number of such applications, which is quite big, from my opinion.

I would suggest, in order to avoid such a risk, consider changing the default Augur web app port to something different from 8080 so that this attack vector has lower probability of being exploited.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello

I continue trying to find new attack vectors related to the described issue and I think there is a new scenario.
I write it here as a comment, not as a separate issue because it's related.

Augur local application (while Augur app is not served through IPFS yet) is served via 127.0.0.1:8080

I would like to note that this is one of the most popular ports in use by applications with similar architecture - default Tomcat port, default testing port for many apps, web apps examples, default new Postgres web based UI client port, some of cryptocurrencies clients use this architecture (NXT for example) etc.

If I understood it correctly, all of these applications can read and write data from localStorage 127.0.0.1:8080. They are in fact share this data area with Augur client.
I other words, risk of one of such apps being compromised is multiplied by the number of such applications, which is quite big, from my opinion.

I would suggest, in order to avoid such a risk, consider changing the default Augur web app port to something different from 8080 so that this attack vector has lower probability of being exploited.

activities.message:
Thanks for testing and confirming!

We are going to work on disabling query-string-based configuration for the app as served via Augur App (although its still necessary for IPFS/static hosted archives). We will provide the configuration through the backend by writing the config file before starting the UI server.

This should fully mitigate this attack vector on localhost.

For IPFS we will do the Query String based configs, but not store the items in localhost after we do a bug fix for our URL routing which will preserve configuration in the URL.

Again this is attackable by someone forming a malicious link, but it won't persist.
activities.markdown_message:

This should fully mitigate this attack vector on localhost.

For IPFS we will do the Query String based configs, but not store the items in localhost after we do a bug fix for our URL routing which will preserve configuration in the URL.

Again this is attackable by someone forming a malicious link, but it won't persist.

activities.message:
Hello, thank you for keeping me updated.
Very cool you are getting rid of local storage for localhost!

The approach with hash URL parameters should also be ok I think, good stuff.
The only thing worries me a little. I'm not deep in JavaScript, but I read some docs about the Service Workers.
Looks like a service worker can be installed on a page visiting ipfs domain so that all the other requests from this page are filtered by it and which is more important , it is persistent.

I could be wrong though, again, don't have deep expertise here .

I found this https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/issues/4025

Not sure it makes sense though, but I will read more about it

Looks like a service worker can be installed on a page visiting ipfs domain so that all the other requests from this page are filtered by it and which is more important , it is persistent.

I could be wrong though, again, don't have deep expertise here .

I found this https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/issues/4025

Not sure it makes sense though, but I will read more about it

activities.message:
Hello guys
Thank you for you feedback, I just receive email you liked my friendliness)

I still have some questions though.

This report is closed as informative but not requiring an immediate action.
It wonders me a little. The issue was raised as critical, passed verification in this state and triaged still in state critical.

Further, regarding the absence of the need of immediate action (as the current status says) - it was fixed urgently the same day, developer rolled out the fix in the evening. It looks "immediate" for me, especially if you check the original comments from the developer which contain words "ASAP" and "data-security vulnerability".
He also confirms the issue is not fully addressed yet.

Now, lets reiterate what's the issue was:

**User visits a link from internet, his Augur application data is replaced by an attacker then - market data, Ethereum addresses, everything.**

I don't know what definition of "critical"  can explain more what "critical" word stands for in security.

But you already rolled out a patch the same day, right.

After that it turned out that there are different other issues:

1. The common and widely used port number, which is shared with other apps. Developer said they are already working on getting rid of local storage after the report.
2. A new issue discovered with Service Worker, which can be injected by a page on the same domain (IPFS) and filter all the consecutive request from Augur web application page, replacing all the real data with whatever is needed to trick a user.

Each of them (especially the second) sounds well, quite critical as for me.

I really like Augur project and was following the public news about development from the beginning. This is a really great idea and implementation.

Unfortunately, I have some sad feelings now. Of course, I read the SLA . - "awards are discretion of Augur" etc. I would like to say that we all here, the testers and hackers, are motivated by the possibility of fair appreciation of our work. All the bugs look just "informative" and "obvious" after they are discovered and urgently fixed.

Thank you for the great technical discussions we hd these days. I really hope this is just unfortunate misunderstanding and the Augur program is really intended to provide fair compensation for participants.

activities.message:
Hello, thank you!

I would like to do a follow up on the our previous discussion with pgebheim

As I understood the plan behind how Augur UI is going to be decentralized, there will be a domain name, say ipfs.augur.net, which under normal circumstances will serve all the HTML files.
In the case Augur loses control on domain name or under massive dDoS, the planned fallback is to serve files through IPFS (third-party) domain.

According to information from  https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/issues/4025 and after my local tests, this should happen under no circumstances, as it is possible that a static web page, residing on the same domain name and served via HTTPS, injects a Service Worker which can intercept and replace all the traffic between Augur single-page web app and node server, including all the javascript source files.
Such a page can be created by anyone and not owned by Augur, just served normally via gateway.ipfs.io  /ipfs/[hash] url. After user opens such a page, all his traffic to Augur node servers becomes immediately compromised.

I did not create a second report for this as the title of the current report describes the  impact pretty well and to some extent caused by similar reasons - the absence of current active page integrity checks.

In order to mitigate this I would suggest to perform some additional checks, whether current page contains unexpected components or/and state.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello, thank you!

I would like to do a follow up on the our previous discussion with pgebheim

As I understood the plan behind how Augur UI is going to be decentralized, there will be a domain name, say ipfs.augur.net, which under normal circumstances will serve all the HTML files.
In the case Augur loses control on domain name or under massive dDoS, the planned fallback is to serve files through IPFS (third-party) domain.

According to information from https://github.com/ipfs/go-ipfs/issues/4025 and after my local tests, this should happen under no circumstances, as it is possible that a static web page, residing on the same domain name and served via HTTPS, injects a Service Worker which can intercept and replace all the traffic between Augur single-page web app and node server, including all the javascript source files.
Such a page can be created by anyone and not owned by Augur, just served normally via gateway.ipfs.io /ipfs/[hash] url. After user opens such a page, all his traffic to Augur node servers becomes immediately compromised.

I did not create a second report for this as the title of the current report describes the impact pretty well and to some extent caused by similar reasons - the absence of current active page integrity checks.

In order to mitigate this I would suggest to perform some additional checks, whether current page contains unexpected components or/and state.

activities.message:
Hello @droblin !

Indeed this is an issue with serving from a shared IPFS endpoint, in fact we have a (public) bug report related to how this could happen on localhost:8080 if someone were also able to run a malicious server on the host machine at any time prior to using Augur.

Augur has no plans for hosting the files itself anywhere, except for being available for download from npm or via the Augur App. So, if someone were to run a an ipfs service to server the Augur UI, that would inherently need to be trusted by the users of that service. There is no plan to, or fallback plant to serve the files from IPFS. It's  just well known that it is possible and in fact people are already doing it.

The recommended way to access augur is by running Augur App on your local machine.

I believe at the end of the day this is an issue with using augur from any untrusted endpoint on the internet, and there really isn't much we can do to save users from themselves in this way.

Here is a link to the tweet describing the localhost version of the attack:
https://twitter.com/peter_szilagyi/status/1024356263164092416

Augur has no plans for hosting the files itself anywhere, except for being available for download from npm or via the Augur App. So, if someone were to run a an ipfs service to server the Augur UI, that would inherently need to be trusted by the users of that service. There is no plan to, or fallback plant to serve the files from IPFS. It's just well known that it is possible and in fact people are already doing it.

The recommended way to access augur is by running Augur App on your local machine.

I believe at the end of the day this is an issue with using augur from any untrusted endpoint on the internet, and there really isn't much we can do to save users from themselves in this way.

Here is a link to the tweet describing the localhost version of the attack:
https://twitter.com/peter_szilagyi/status/1024356263164092416

activities.message:
Ahh, thanks for clarification @pgebheim !

I've got an impression IPFS is the official and recommended fallback scenario for decentralization, especially after reading answers to this question on Stack Exchange https://augur.stackexchange.com/questions/409/augur-and-ipfs-utilization 

Good to know localhost is the only recommended way to run Augur.

activities.message:
I can imagine how many rants you are reading per day from participants. So here is another one :)

I do understand it's Friday evening and probably nobody cares, but please find time to read it, at least from entertaining point of view, so that you discuss it with your colleagues just for fun.

Putting that high bounty values raises the bar for both bounty hacker and a company.
Someone is going to find it and probably it's going to be in an unexpected place and even look stupid and simple. Like all the bugs actually after discovered.

In your SLA you say the severity of a bug is calculated by CVSS metrics.

Here is what I get with it https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H

It is only a short user interaction was needed to nuke the application completely and replace it with fake data.
It's like after you open a link from internet, your online banking opened in next browser tab is replaced by fishing site.

Low severity... How would you call it if it happened to your online banking and you sent funds to /dev/null ?

So there are all the factors in this report: the vulnerability, the attack vector, the impact.
Unfortunately, it's not related to Smart Contracts, where The Critical Bug is expected to be found. It's good old frame jacking due to broken navigation and missed X-Frame-Options, leading to critical consequences.

Now, the potential impacts of it.

- In the case it is discovered by someone not participating in bug bounty program. What would he do? Well, the logical step in the case someone wanted to exploit it wold be, for example, sending out fishing links to Augur users and just proxy the real application responses, replacing all the Ethereum addresses with his own.
Besides the fund loss, how would it impact the Augur app adoption?

- Someone could find it and just create post a Medium or somewhere else, describing how is it easy to hijack Augur's  UI data.
Again, how would it impact the Augur app user base?

But this stupid simple small and critical bug was found in Augur's bug bounty program, the one with very high bonuses for critical bugs and very low expectations of such bugs being actually found.

Am I right?

activities.message:
Hi droblin, 

The engineering team has further assessed this report, and has concluded to pay out the maximum as a medium severity report (the maximum UI severity assessment). We really appreciate you taking the time to write up this report, include thorough details, and communicate with the team.  

Thanks!

The Forecast Foundation OU
activities.markdown_message:
Hi droblin,

The engineering team has further assessed this report, and has concluded to pay out the maximum as a medium severity report (the maximum UI severity assessment). We really appreciate you taking the time to write up this report, include thorough details, and communicate with the team.

Thanks!

The Forecast Foundation OU

activities.message:
Hello, thank you for the bounty. I appreciate it.

But I'm still missing some understanding here. Oh, I feel how I bothered you already ) Sorry for that.

You are saying this is solely UI part and according to SLA it can be only have "medium" maximum severity.

Lets return to the Augur application structure. It has 3 main components which are in scope of our discussion here:
Node server, Electron app and UI part.
Node server and Electron app are in fact tied together. They are packaged in application and when you start it, both Node part and Electron UI are starting.

Then, this combined application opens browser with url parameters, containing the "augur-node" part around which we had all this issue with.

So, for me it looks like that: **Node**+Electron mistakenly pass without any integrity control configuration parameter to the UI part which, in turn, is trying to call them back using this parameter.

This sounds a little bit casuistically, right? Words can be played the other way around and the application components can be re-combined in whatever way is more suitable, depending on a person's position.

But, using common sense approach (at least from my understanding, I admit this) - words "**Replace users UI with fake data remotely**" and demonstration of how to do this on practice -  don't they touch the nerve?

 I mean, do you genuine believe this is a "medium UI level issue"?

If so, please let me know so that I really stop this ranting here.
activities.markdown_message:
Hello, thank you for the bounty. I appreciate it.

But I'm still missing some understanding here. Oh, I feel how I bothered you already ) Sorry for that.

You are saying this is solely UI part and according to SLA it can be only have "medium" maximum severity.

Lets return to the Augur application structure. It has 3 main components which are in scope of our discussion here:
Node server, Electron app and UI part.
Node server and Electron app are in fact tied together. They are packaged in application and when you start it, both Node part and Electron UI are starting.

Then, this combined application opens browser with url parameters, containing the "augur-node" part around which we had all this issue with.

So, for me it looks like that: Node+Electron mistakenly pass without any integrity control configuration parameter to the UI part which, in turn, is trying to call them back using this parameter.

This sounds a little bit casuistically, right? Words can be played the other way around and the application components can be re-combined in whatever way is more suitable, depending on a person's position.

But, using common sense approach (at least from my understanding, I admit this) - words "Replace users UI with fake data remotely" and demonstration of how to do this on practice - don't they touch the nerve?

I mean, do you genuine believe this is a "medium UI level issue"?

If so, please let me know so that I really stop this ranting here.

activities.message:
Couple things here:

- The x frame issue (the main thing here) was brought up by another bounty hunter about a month ago. 
- The maximum payout on the Augur bounty page for UI issues is Medium (the reason for this is we believe the contracts to be much more secure than the UI, and it doesn’t make sense to have higher bounty payouts for the UI until it is substantially more hardened/reviewed and lower hanging fruit issues are found (like missing headers which can be found with scanners)
- This issue is due to the UI server, which technically isn’t even in scope but it’s a good issue to bring up!
- I think it’s a high UI level issue, and even though it’s above medium which is the highest listed payout we can discretionaily increase the payout, which I’m going to do now. Thanks!

vulnerability_information_html:
Summary: A third party attacking site can fake UI data - markets, categories and other

Description: A third party site can include a hidden iframe which can override "augur-node" configuration variable of a running augur application. This variable is persisted in localStorage. In the case of browser page reload (user action or browser/OS crash), the normal "augur-node" websockets endpoint will be replaced with the provided by attacker so that all the markets data, addresses and transactions can be masqueraded.

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Start Augur application
  2. Open application
  3. Click on "markets" tab
  4. Start web socket server on port 8081 (different from the Augur one)
  5. Open HTML page with iframe which loads Augur's initial page with "augur-node" parameter overwritten by new value, for example 192.168.31.204:8081 in my test case
  6. Observe "Application" data tab in developer tools, the augur-node variable is set to new value: 192.168.31.204:8081
  7. Reload opened application (simulating user occasional reload or browser crash, or a user opening Augur app form bookmarks )
  8. Observe the log console of the web sockets server: you can see requests for categories, market data etc
  9. Observe the Augur application UI - no data is provided as the fake web sockets server has been called, we only need to add implementation and return fake data there to get user misdirected

Impact: Can lead to fund and reputation loss

I also mentioned the danger of it in https://hackerone.com/bugs?subject=user&report_id=385125

Augur application should not be possible to load in an iframe and manipulate user's settings. For example, Gmail doesn't allow this.

Also, storing important configuration data in localStorage is a very bad practice

Supporting Material/References:

  • HTML page implementing iframe which sets wrong data
  • server.js Simple web socket in node

Impact

Can lead to fund and reputation loss

I also mentioned the danger of it in https://hackerone.com/bugs?subject=user&report_id=385125
